facts.text: Hirday Ram was the owner of the suit property.

anchor.surface_text: Brief facts giving rise to these appeals are as follows One Hirday Ram was the owner of the suit property. He had three wives, namely, Kubja, Pari and Uttamdassi.

facts.text: Hirday Ram had three wives: Kubja, Pari and Uttamdassi.

anchor.surface_text: He had three wives, namely, Kubja, Pari and Uttamdassi. Kubja had pre- deceased Hirday Ram leaving behind a daughter named Tikami.

facts.text: Kubja pre-deceased Hirday Ram leaving behind a daughter named Tikami.

anchor.surface_text: Kubja had pre- deceased Hirday Ram leaving behind a daughter named Tikami. During his life time, Hirday Ram made a Will dated 1.10.1938

facts.text: Hirday Ram made a Will dated 1.10.1938.

anchor.surface_text: During his life time, Hirday Ram made a Will dated 1.10.1938 whereby he bequeathed a part of his property to his daughter Tikami

facts.text: By the Will, Hirday Ram bequeathed a part of his property to Tikami and the remaining to Kubja and Uttamdassi for maintenance without power to alienate, to revert to Tikami after their death.

anchor.surface_text: whereby he bequeathed a part of his property to his daughter Tikami and the remaining property was given to his two other wives, named above, for their maintenance with the condition that they would not have the power to alienate the same in any manner. As per the Will, after the death of the above two wives of Hirday Ram, the property was to revert back to his daughter Tikami as absolute owner.

facts.text: Hirday Ram and his second wife Pari died in 1939.

anchor.surface_text: After the death of Hirday Ram and his second wife Pari in 1939, the property in question came to be vested with the third wife, Uttamdassi as per the terms of the Will.

facts.text: After 1939, property vested with Uttamdassi as per the Will.

anchor.surface_text: After the death of Hirday Ram and his second wife Pari in 1939, the property in question came to be vested with the third wife, Uttamdassi as per the terms of the Will.

facts.text: After Hindu Succession Act 1956 came into force, Uttamdassi sold part of property to Sandup on 28.11.1958.

anchor.surface_text: After the coming into force of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956, Uttamdassi claiming to be the absolute owner sold a part of the property to one Sandup on 28.11.1958

facts.text: Sandup is predecessor-in-interest of respondent Nos.1 and 2.

anchor.surface_text: predecessor-in-interest of respondent Nos.1 and 2 herein. The said Sandup mortgaged back the property to Uttamdassi

facts.text: Sandup mortgaged back the property to Uttamdassi.

anchor.surface_text: The said Sandup mortgaged back the property to Uttamdassi who on 2.12.1958 made a gift of another property in favour of respondent No.3

facts.text: Uttamdassi made a gift of another property to respondent No.3 on 2.12.1958.

anchor.surface_text: who on 2.12.1958 made a gift of another property in favour of respondent No.3 herein who in turn sold to it respondent No.4.

facts.text: Respondent No.3 sold the property to respondent No.4.

anchor.surface_text: herein who in turn sold to it respondent No.4. The appellant herein is a daughter of Tikami and granddaughter of Hirday Ram

facts.text: Appellant is daughter of Tikami and granddaughter of Hirday Ram.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant herein is a daughter of Tikami and granddaughter of Hirday Ram filed a suit challenging the alienation made by Uttamdassi

facts.text: Appellant filed suit challenging alienation by Uttamdassi, decreed by trial court on 12.7.1961.

anchor.surface_text: filed a suit challenging the alienation made by Uttamdassi seeking a decree for declaration that the alienation made by Uttamdassi would not affect her reversionary rights. The suit was decreed by the trial court on 12.7.1961.

facts.text: Appeal by Uttamdassi dismissed on 25.1.1963, declaratory decree final.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal filed by Uttamdassi was dismissed on 25.1.1963. Thus the said declaratory decree became final as it was not put to challenge in further appeal in the High Court.

facts.text: Uttamdassi gifted the property sold to Sandup to respondent No.5 on 24.5.1975.

anchor.surface_text: On 24.5.1975 Uttamdassi gifted the property sold by her to Sandup in 1958 in favour of respondent No.5.

facts.text: Appellant filed second suit challenging 1975 gift, trial court dismissed, first appellate court accepted on appeal, gift void ab initio, decree final.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant herein again filed a suit challenging the said alienation also and seeking a declaration that the said alienation made by Uttamdassi would not affect her reversionary rights. The trial court dismissed the suit but an appeal preferred by the appellant herein was accepted by the First Appellate Court

facts.text: Uttamdassi gifted part of property to respondent No.5 by Will on 27.12.1986.

anchor.surface_text: It is relevant to mention herein that Uttamdassi had gifted a part of the property in favour of respondent No.5 by way of a Will on 27.12.1986.

facts.text: Uttamdassi died on 1.1.1987.

anchor.surface_text: She died on 1.1.1987. After the death of Uttamdassi, appellant the granddaughter of the original owner Hirday Ram

facts.text: After Uttamdassi's death, appellant filed suit for possession based on two earlier declaratory decrees, trial court dismissed on 22.8.1989.

anchor.surface_text: After the death of Uttamdassi, appellant the granddaughter of the original owner Hirday Ram brought a suit for possession of the suit property being the nearest reversioner and on the basis of the two earlier declaratory decrees obtained by her. The trial court dismissed the suit on 22.8.1989.

facts.text: Trial court in 1989 suit relied on V.Tulasamma vs. V.Sesha Reddy 1977 3 SCC 99 holding Uttamdassi absolute owner under Section 14(1) HSA 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Relying upon a judgment of this Court in the case of V.Tulasamma vs. V.Sesha Reddy 1977 3 SCC 99 holding, inter alia, that though the suit property was given to the wives of Hirday Ram as limited owners but in view of Section 14(1) of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 Uttamdassi became the absolute owner

facts.text: First appellate court dismissed appellant's appeal on 30.9.1991.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal filed by the appellant was dismissed on 30.9.1991 by the First Appellate Court

facts.text: High Court dismissed second appeal by impugned judgment.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant preferred a regular second appeal which has been dismissed by the impugned judgment of the High Court

facts.text: Division Bench referred appeals to larger bench on 27th October, 2004 due to contradictory views in Teg Singh, Kesar Singh, Balwant Singh.

anchor.surface_text: SANTOSH HEGDE, J. Noticing certain contradictory views in three different judgments of this Court in Teg Singh vs. Charan Singh 1977 2 SCC 732, Kesar Singh vs. Sadhu 1996 7 SCC 711 and Balwant Singh vs. Daulat Singh 1997 7 SCC 137 , a Division Bench of 2-Judges of this Court referred the instant appeals for disposal by a larger bench by its referral order dated 27th October, 2004,

facts.text: High Court held earlier declaratory decrees do not operate as res judicata due to contrary interpretation in V.Tulasamma.

anchor.surface_text: holding inter alia that interpretation of Section 14 of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 was a pure question of law and the earlier decrees obtained on the interpretation of law in the case of Mst. Karmi vs. Amru Ors. AIR 1971 SC 745 cannot operate as res judicata in the face of the contrary interpretation put to Section 14 in the later decision of this Court in V.Tulasammas case supra

facts.text: Supreme Court holds declaratory decrees contrary to V.Tulasamma do not bind and suit for possession not maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: In the instant case, in our opinion, the High Court rightly held that the declaratory decrees obtained by the appellant being contrary to the judgment in Tulasammas case supra would not be of any assistance to the appellant to obtain the possession of the suit property.

facts.text: Appellant contended two declaratory decrees final, entitle to possession, res judicata applies.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel appearing for the appellant contended that the two declaratory decrees obtained by the appellant declaring her right as a reversioner to the property in question having become final, she is entitled to the fruits of the said decree.

facts.text: Court rejects appellant's contention, holds res judicata does not apply to decrees contrary to law in V.Tulasamma.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, examined from any angle, we do not find any merit in this appeal.

facts.text: Hindu Succession Act, 1956 enlarged Uttamdassi's limited estate to absolute ownership under Section 14(1).

anchor.surface_text: since on the coming into force of the Hindu Succession Act by virtue of Section 14(1) the limited right got by Uttamdassi under the Will got enlarged to an absolute right in the suit property.

facts.text: Appeal before Supreme Court dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, examined from any angle, we do not find any merit in this appeal.

issues.text: The point for our consideration in this case is whether the finding of the High Court in the impugned judgment that the earlier decree obtained by the appellant being declaratory in nature would not operate as res judicata in favour of the appellant and would not enable her to obtain possession through the court of law by filing a suit for possession, is correct in law or not ?

anchor.surface_text: V.Tulasamma vs. V.Sesha Reddy  1977  3 SCC 99 holding, inter alia, that though the suit property was given to the wives of Hirday Ram as limited owners but in view of Section 14(1) of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 Uttamdassi became the absolute owner of the suit property and had the right to alienate the same by way of sale, gift or will.
